STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 21, 2025
Jennifer Stevens
Samaritas-Bay
1024 Professional Dr.
Flint, MI, 48532-3635
Re: License #: CB250296641
SI #: 2025SIC0000936
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
248-860-3317
Enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000936
Special Investigation Intake Date: 08/13/2025
License #: CB250296641
Licensee Group Organization: Samaritas
Licensee Designee: Rachel Sykes
Chief Administrator: Jennifer Stevens
Agency Name: SAMARITAS - BAY
Agency Address: 1024 PROFESSIONAL DR
FLINT, MI 48532-3635
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/17/2025
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
8/14/2025 5:06 PM Phone Special Investigation Initiation
8/15/2025 3:27 PM Email Document received or sent
8/15/2025 3:29 PM Email Document received or sent

10/20/2025 2:43 PM Email Document received or sent
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency allowed the child to come to the foster home with a
cell phone in which the location was turned on giving location
information on the foster family and compromising the safety of
the child and foster family. Additionally, the child came to the
home with a pencil lead in her ear, and the foster care worker did
not effectively communicate with the foster parent around the
foster child's medical needs in this area or related to the foster
child's medical health needs.
Investigation Interviews:
On 8/15/2025 I interviewed Foster Parent by telephone related to
the allegations. Foster Parent reported she had several concerns
with agency. She does not understand why the agency is
investigating her and seeking to revoke her license and won’t let
her transfer to another agency. She reported suspecting the
reason is retaliation due to her having to sue the agency related to
back payment issues. She reported it was the agency who did not
communicate well with her; and was not supporting her in the way
that they should have been when she had Child A placed with her.
She reported Child A was in her care from 6/17/2024 to
11/20/2024; and she was Child A 's fifth foster care home
placement. She reported Child A’s placement with her was her
first experience as a foster parent; and she put her license on hold
in October 2024 while she was caring for Child A. She said the
agency is trying to make it seem as if she did not do things, that
she did not get medical and mental health care for Child A, but it
was the agency’s failure.
She said Child A came to her home, with an iPhone in her hand,
and Foster Care Worker (FCW) failed to ask her whether it was
okay for Child A to have a phone. All FCW did was ask Child A if
Child A had gotten permission from her prior caregiver/her half-
sister to have the phone; and when Child A said, yes, told Foster
2

Parent it was okay for Child A to have the iPhone because it was
from Child A’s family. Foster Parent said she did not know Child
A’s iPhone had the location aspect turned on until a week later;
and by then the iPhone had shown seven prior families her
address. Foster Parent acknowledged not knowing if FCW knew
the location indicator of the iPhone was turned on. She said FCW
had told her the phone was off; that Child A could play games and
facetime, as long as, the phone was turned on, but Child A could
not make phone calls. Foster Parent reported Child A asked her
to connect the iPhone to Wi-Fi and when Foster Parent did, Foster
Parent saw it was connected to seven of Child A’s family
members. Foster Parent said she turned the location off on the
iPhone, but every day it would be turned on again by Child A's
half-sister, who had the Apple ID. Foster Parent reported asking
FCW to come get the iPhone; and FCW told her FCW did not
have time to do so. Foster Parent did not give a specific reason
as to why she didn’t take the phone to the agency or send it to
them. She said she took the iPhone to an Apple store, and they
told her there was nothing they could do. They advised that she
turn the iPhone off, which she did. She said she got a government
cell phone for Child A. She reported returning Child A to the
agency on 11/29/2024(Child A’s case file showed Child A
replacement date as 11/20/2024) and the agency gave Child A’s
new family the option as to whether Child A could have a phone,
unlike what they gave her. She said the agency also alleged she
was irate when she came up to the office and complained. She
said she ended up throwing the phone away but did not
distinguish if that was the government phone she purchased or
the iPhone.
Foster Parent also reported being upset with FCW for not
following up on Child A’s medical needs, just like she said FCW
did not do about the iPhone issue. She said it’s alleged in a
special evaluation report against her foster home that she took
Child A for ear surgery without permission; and that she refused
take Child A for her mental health treatment, which are untrue.
She reported knowing after Child A’s placement date she had 30
days to get a medical exam for Child A. She reported she had
noticed Child A had prescribed nose drops for some reason, and
Child A kept picking in her ear. She took Child A to the doctor
within the first week of Child A being with her for an examination
about these issues. The doctor told her there was something in
Child A’s ear. Child A told the doctor that since she did not have a
cuticle, she stuck a pencil in her ear. The doctor surmised it was
a piece of lead in Child A’s ear; and sent them to specialist, who
said they could not remove the item due to Child A not being able
3

to sit still. Child A needed to have pencil lead surgically removed.
Foster Parent said she told FCW about all of this and sent the
paperwork about Child A needing the surgery to FCW. FCW told
her, okay; and never told her the agency needed to get parental
consent before she could proceed with Child A’s ear procedure.
Foster Parent reported never hearing anything more about Child
A’s ear surgical procedure, which occurred on 6/27/2024, until
about two weeks after the procedure. Foster Parent changed that
statement to say she did not hear more about her proceeding on
this matter until August 2025. She received a telephone call from
a children’s services worker, who had FCW on the other end,
asking her why she hadn’t told FCW about the procedure so that
FCW could have obtained parental consent. She reported being
surprised by that as she had sent the paperwork about it to FCW.
Foster Parent reported that as a new foster parent she was not
sure of all things, but she thought she had acted appropriately in
getting Child A’s medical care, which occurred outpatient on
6/27/2024. FCW never instructed her to not follow through, or to
wait.
Foster Parent reported in terms of mental health services for Child
A it was the agency that failed to obtain consent for Child A to get
the medication Child A needed for her health. She said she never
refused to take Child A for treatment. She said it took about three
months to get Child A’s mental service through community mental
due to Child A changing counties. She lived in Washtenaw County
and Child A previously resided in Wayne County. She got Child A
in therapy and Child A was seeing Therapist B, from September
2024 until Child A left her foster home in November 2024 and
Child did not miss sessions. She reported there came a time that
Child A was in outpatient psychiatric treatment. The outpatient
psychiatric treatment came to be, after she had gotten a call from
a lawyer (the specific lawyer was not named) about her and Child
A testifying in court. She said this was on 10/28/2024 and she
spoke with Child A about possibly having to testify about things
that occurred in Child A’s birth home. She reported on 10/28/2024
she learned after the fact, via email from the school, that Child A
had gone to school and had kicked someone. Foster Parent said
when she spoke with Child A, that same day, about the incident,
Child A also said she had taken a pair of scissors and put them to
her chest to hurt herself. Foster Parent reported she was unable
to confirm this with the school, due to it being at the end of the
day, so she tried contacting the agency, and FCW about the
incident without success. Concerned, she took Child A to Motts
hospital who told her they could not admit Child A. She said the
hospital explained to her she could go through community mental
4

health; and someone could admit Child A for 10 days or she could
go outpatient for two weeks. Foster Parent said New Oakland
Family Center (NOFC), which was one hour away from her home,
was the only one who could take Child A. Foster Parent said she
chose this outpatient option via NOFC due to her job and Child A’s
school situation. She said she called FCW back about these
services, but FCW was not helping in getting Child A into
somewhere quicker. Foster Parent said she did all she was told to
do by the hospital, and Child A was to start outpatient services on
10/29/2024. She said FCW told her they needed to get parental
consent for this service. Birth Mom consented for this service at a
11/1/2024 court hearing. Child A started out patient services on
11/4/2024. Foster Parent A reported during Child A’s treatment,
Dr. H wanted to diagnose Child A with Attention Deficit
Hyperattention Disorder (ADHD), Oppositional Defiant Disorder
and place her on medication. Foster Parent reported advising
FCW and FCW said she would contact the parents about
providing consent and get back with Foster Parent. She said
FCW contacted her later and said consensus could not be
reached for Child A to be placed on psychotropic medication.
Birth Mom was open to giving consent, but Birth Dad said no.
Foster Parent reported she thought more could have be done to
have the doctor move forward with medication for Child A. She
asked FCW what more could be done. FCW advised her nothing
more could be done without parental consent and to let Child A
finish the outpatient treatment for Child A at NOFC. Foster Parent
said she told FCW that since FCW was not doing anything to get
consent for Child A’s medication treatment, FCW should transport
Child A to finish the outpatient treatment. FCW told her FCW
could not and told Foster Parent, Foster Parent was refusing to
follow through with getting Child A’s treatment. Foster Parent
disagreed with FCW’s assessment of the this situation.
Additionally, Foster Parent reported FCW was not helpful in
getting Child A’s Medicaid changed over. She reported that when
Child A came to her, Washtenaw County where she lives had
discontinued accepting Molina Medicaid; and she tried to get Child
A’s plan changed to United Health. She spoke with DHHS
(Department of Health and Human Services) about this and was
told by DHHS they needed FCW to report the request to them
directly; as they also needed specific information about Child A
(i.e. date of birth, social security number, reason for change)
verified to them. Foster Parent told FCW this information via
email; and FCW reported not being at her desk to give the
information to the DHHS service person. FCW was to follow up
on this later but never did.
5

On 9/4/2025 I interviewed Program Manager (PM)1 by telephone
about the allegations. PM 1 was interviewed because Chief
Administrator had reported via email on 8/14/2025 that PM 1 and
PM 2 were providing supervisory oversight on Child A ‘s and the
family’s case. PM 1 reported he was not providing this supervisory
oversight prior to May 2025. He is the program manager and as
the program manager he would not have heard about Child A
arriving at the foster home with a cell phone with a location turned
on; but he recalled vaguely hearing something about that. He
reported Supervisor who left the agency in May 2025 and over
saw Child A’s case would have handled that situation. He reported
knowing nothing about Child A having a pen or pencil lead in her
ear. He reported that if that had been the situation and Child A
needed some type of surgical procedure he can’t believe FCW
would not have sought consent and worked with Foster Parent on
Child A’s medical needs. He reported maybe Foster Parent was
not aware of what FCW was doing behind the scenes to handle
this matter.
PM 1 reported his only involvement with Child A’s case was
around getting the IEP (Individual Education Plan) when Child A
was in Foster Parent home. He explained the process to Foster
Parent; and that Child A’s parents would need to consent. He
reported Program Manager (PM)2 would also not have information
about these allegations because PM 2 was the agency’s
supervisor in then Lansing area prior to her promotion to program
manager in January 2025. He reported Foster Parent has
litigation going on pertaining to the agency; and staff are not
permitted to talk to her. He reported there is an agency
recommendation for revocation of Foster Parent’s foster home
license, and he suspects this complaint came likely due to that.
On 9/4/2025 I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) by
telephone about the allegations. She reported being Child A’s
worker during the time that Child A was placed in Foster Parent’s
home. She was assigned to the case in February 2023 with the
agency until Child A’s case was reassigned to another worker in
May 2025. FCW denied the allegations as reported by Foster
Parent. She said she took Child A to Foster Parent’s home for the
placement, but she did not see the iPhone or know about it until
about one to two weeks after the placement date. She said Foster
Parent contacted her and she advised Foster Parent to turn the
location service off. She also advised Foster Parent that they
could meet, and Foster Parent could give her the iPhone; or
Foster Parent could bring the iPhone to the office. FCW said
6

Foster Parent wanted to keep the iPhone and change the setting
so that it could be connected to her family’s plan for Child A. FCW
reported she agreed to what Foster Parent wanted; and told
Foster Parent okay, provided Foster Parent turned the tracking
mechanism on the phone off. FCW reported Foster Parent did not
express concern about the phone again until Child A was being
replaced from her home. FCW said Foster Parent was more upset
then, when she told Foster Parent that Child A could not take the
phone Child A had to the new placement. At that time FCW said
she did not know whether the phone in question was the same
phone Child A had come to Foster Parent’s home with, or was a
new phone Foster Parent had purchased for Child A. FCW
reported she was just trying to rectify the issue so that Child A’s
new foster parent didn’t feel like Foster Parent had relating to
possible tracking issues. She tried to explain that to Foster Parent,
but Foster Parent was not satisfied with that. FCW denied telling
Foster Parent she did not have time to come get the phone. FCW
reported various home visits with Foster Parent after Child A’s
initial placement where Foster Parent could have turned over the
iPhone if she did not want to keep it; and Foster Parent did not
turn over the phone.
FCW reported as it related to Child A having a pencil lead in her
ear that Foster Parent had texted her one week after Child A’s
placement about the matter. FCW did not recall the specific date
but recalled the text mentioning Child A needing a procedure. She
reported there being nothing in the text about anesthesia or that
Child A would need to be put to sleep for the procedure. She
reported Foster Parent had a habit of sending her multiple texts,
about various things, so she did not know that consent was
needed for the procedure. She said Foster Parent moved forward
with getting the procedure to remove the object from Child A’s ear
without getting parental consent for the procedure; but Foster
Parent didn’t know; and she did not realize consent was required.
She said she explained the circumstances to Child A’s parents
and Birth Mom and Birth Dad were okay with the matter. FCW
reported there was no special evaluation against Foster Parent
over this misunderstanding.
FCW reported there was another matter that came up involving
parental consent that Foster Parent had concern with and
complained about. Foster Parent wanted Child A to be placed on
psychotropic medication; and FCW had previously discussed with
Foster Parent what issues required parental consent. FCW
reported the matter of medication for Child A came up after a
reported incident with Child A at school. Reportedly Child A, not
7

the school, reported to Foster Parent that Child A held scissors to
her stomach and said she did not want to live. Foster Parent took
Child A to the children’s psychiatric hospital and the hospital
recommended NOFC for services. FCW said parental consent
was needed for the NOFC assessment and the agency got
consent from the parents, at a court hearing on 11/1/2024 with
Birth Mom signing the necessary consent; and she submitted the
consent paperwork on 11/2/2024. She said Child A had the
NOFC assessment and it resulted in a recommendation for
psychotropic medication. She said there was a problem getting
consent from Child A’s parents for the medication. FCW reported
the agency had also filed an emergency medical petition for the
medication issue and there was a hearing. Birth Mom and NOFC
were present, and Birth Mom said she would consent. NOFC tried
to get both parents’ consent, and since Birth Dad said no, NOFC
would not take only Birth Mom’s consent to proceed with
medication for Child A. FCW reported once Birth Dad would not
consent to the medication for Child A, Foster Parent stop taking
Child A for her outpatient treatment appointment at NOFC. Foster
Parent reported since Child A was not going to get the
psychotropic medication there was no need, she would not be
completing the two week’s program. FCW reported Foster Parent
alleged Foster Parent had transportation issues, and when FCW
offered transportation, Foster Parent told her not to bother. When
she went to pick Child A up for an appointment in mid-November
2024, Foster Parent had sent Child A to school. Foster Parent
reported she felt Child A did not need to go. Child A was
terminated from the NOFC outpatient treatment because Child A
had apparently missed too many days. FCW reported the special
evaluation against Foster Parent was related to this matter.
FCW reported prior to Child A’s placement with Foster Parent,
Child A was in therapy in Detroit. She reported since Foster
Parent resided in another county, they had to go through
community mental health (CMH). FCW did not know how long the
process took to get Child A in therapy. She indicated Foster
Parent took care of that. She did not recall Foster Parent asking
for her assistance; because if a Foster Parent is able to take care
of the process, she as the worker, would not get involved unless
assistance is asked for. She reported Child A got enrolled in
therapy and was seeing Therapist B weekly via CMH in
Washtenaw County. There was no other medical matter Foster
Parent asked her assistance on.
Document Review:
Child A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
8

• Child A was placed in Samaritas’ care on 2/23/2023.
• She is a temporary court ward.
• She was placed in Foster Parent’s home from 6/17/2024 to
11/20/2024.
MISACWIS Foster home visits’ social work contacts that indicated:
• On 6/18/2024(a day off the documented MISACWIS
6/17/2024 placement date for Child A’s placement with
Foster Parent) a home visit was conducted that FCW
moved Child A into the new placement; completed intake
packet with the new placement. That the home was
appropriate and no needs were reported from child or foster
parent.
• On 6/24/2024, Child A is up to date on her medical and
dental, and no needs were reported from the foster parent.
• On 7/10/2024 Child A was adjusting well; she was up to
date on her medical and dental. Child A had an intake for
therapy; no needs were reported from the foster parent
• On 8/14/2024 and 9/23/2024: except for the foster parent
reporting on 8/14/2024 wanting permission to take Child A
on a cruise; and reporting on 9/23/2024 a plan to rescind
her 30-day request to have Child A replaced, no needs
were reported from the foster parent.
• On 10/21/2024 Foster Parent reported Child A’s behaviors
had been better in recent weeks; and that no needs were
reported from the child or the foster parent.
• On 11/20/2024 FCW transported Child A to her new foster
home.
Email documents from FCW that showed:
• A copy of a NOFC consent for treatment signed by Birth
Mom, dated 11/1/2024.
• A copy of a medication petition signed by FCW and
Supervisor. The petition indicated that Child A needed
medication. NOFC had attempted to get consent from birth
parents and Birth Dad had not consented.
Emails from Foster Parent with various documents she forwarded
to staff at Samaritas, and the Division of Child Welfare Licensing
(DCWL) Director related to concerns she has that Samaritas is
seeking to take her license and her denial of allegations by the
agency. The couple of relevant emails related to this complaint
were:
• A copy of a 10/28/2024 text or email she received from
Child A’s school related to Child A receiving a behavior
write-up. Of Child A having kicked students in school
9

during lunch this day, and Foster Parent showing she
forwarded that information to the agency.
• Copy of a 10/28/2024 University of Michigan statement
showing Child A was seen at the hospital and was
excused from school until Child A was seen by a
psychiatric on 10/30/2024.
• A text from Foster Parent to FCW which indicated she
expects Child A’s insurance to be fixed today; and she
believes it’s neglect not to have switched it prior.
• A text from FCW indicating Child A has insurance and later
asking whether medication had been recommended for
Child A.
• Copy of back-and-forth texts between Foster Parent and
FCW related to Child A’s outpatient treatment visits. The
texts did not show dates. Foster Parent indicated Child A
has 4 more visits, that the days Child A attend outpatient
day care is, Thursday, Friday, Monday and Tuesday
(9:00am- 3:00PM). That since Birth Dad has refused to
give consent for treatment she asked FCW to transport.
FCW reported she would be able to transport for the next
day and then that she would transport for the next day and
the coming upcoming Monday. Foster Parent reported
since no one else could commit for the other two days it
would be best for Child A to stay at school. That she had
already spoken with the school related to completing Child
A's IEP.
Copy of Foster Parent ‘s special evaluation report dated 6/10/2025
that showed:
• A 11/15/2024 intake date; and an allegation of Foster
Parent refusing to take Child A to outpatient treatment
appointments, and the treatment terminated due to Child A
missing too many days.
• Additionally, allegations of domestic violence between
Foster Parent and Foster Parent’s Mate.
• The special evaluation found Foster Parent and Foster
Parent’s Mate in noncompliance of the foster home
medical and dental care rule, and foster home evaluation
rule related to providing accurate and truthful information
on an ongoing basis pertaining to parenting skills and
strategies for building healthy relationships with children;
along with an additionally findings related to the foster
home applicant/licensee/applicant responsibilities of
allowing access to the home, providing accurate and
truthful information on an going basis and the
applicant’s/licensee’s family history, marriage status and
10

history including current or previous level of family
functioning and any current or previous incidents of
domestic violence, or elder or child abuse as a perpetrator
or victim.
• Revocation of Foster Parent’s and Foster Parent’s Mate’s
license was recommended.
Updated service plans (USP) for 4/24/2024-7/22/2024 that
indicated:
• Foster Parent reported no need during this reporting period.
• Child A was doing well in the foster home placement.
• Foster Parent received Child A’s Medicaid number and
consent for emergency care treatment at placement.
USP for 7/23/2024-10/18/2024 that indicated:
• Child A continues to adjust in the foster home and is doing
well. There are concerns with her behavior, and she is in
therapy now.
• Foster Parent reported no needs during the reporting
period.
Both USPs indicated Child A had behaviors of kicking, hitting and
needing consistent re-direction as a reason she was split from
placement with a sibling. Neither USP showed a parent/agency
treatment plan agreement (PATPA) signed by Foster Parent.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed there is opposing
reporting by agency staff related to the allegations. There is not
sufficient evidence to support the allegations or to support a lack
of the agency worker not working directly with the child, foster
parent or other relevant parties.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plan.
Section (5) An agency shall involve the child’s parent or parents and the
Description foster parents in the development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents’ and the foster parent’s role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to
and review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the child and the
child’s family is confidential.
Violation Additional Findings of Noncompliance.
Type
11

Allegation The foster parent and required agency staff did not sign Child A’s
parent agency treatment plan agreement (PATPA) while Child A
was in the foster parent’s care.
Investigation Interviews:
On 10/20/2025 I had a follow up telephone contact with FCW
related to the PATPA for Child A’s 4/24/2024-7/22/2024 and
7/23/2024-10/18/2024 USP not being documented in MISACWIS.
FCW checked the agency’s electronic system and located both
documents and emailed them to me. Neither treatment plan she
provided was signed by Foster Parent. Nor were they signed by
her and her supervisor. She reported Foster Parent must not have
ever signed a PATPA. She could not give a reason as to why that
existed. Nor as to why the treatment plans were not signed by her
or her supervisor.
Document Review:
Child A’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• A 4/24/2024-7/22/2024 and 7/23/204-10/16/2024 USPs.
• No PATPA for Foster Parent related to Child A, signed by
Foster Parent for the above stated USPs.
An email copy of the PATPA for Child A for Foster Parent received
from FCW on 10/20/2025 for reporting periods of
4/24/2024-7/22/2024 and 7/23/204-10/18/2024 which showed:
• Neither PATPA was signed by Foster Parent, FCW or her
supervisor.
Analysis Based on interviews and review of documents, the evidence
showed the agency is in violation of this rule. The agency did not
have proof that it reviewed the treatment plan with the foster
parent; nor obtained the foster parent’s and agency foster
worker’s and supervisor’s signature on the treatment plan.
Conclusion Violation Established
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
October 20, 2025
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 21, 2025
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
13
